<s_map><s_node-0><s_text>Week Two: Marketing environment & Market Research</s_text><s_node-1><s_text>Marketing Environment</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>Micro</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Stakeholders</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>A stakeholder can be any group or individual who can affect or are affected by the achievement of organisational goals.</s_text><sep/><s_text>3 types</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>External stakeholders</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>e.g. government, pressure groups, community, professional bodies</s_text></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Connected stakeholders</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>e.g. shareholders customers, suppliers, bankers</s_text></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Internal stakeholders</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>e.g. Staff, managers</s_text></s_node-6></s_node-5><sep/><s_text>Four different reactions to stakeholders</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>Proactive</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>address problem before it becomes a problem</s_text></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Reactive</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>Ignore until forced</s_text></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Defensive</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>block and fight... PR wars, lobbying, courts</s_text></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Accommodate</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>accept responsibility and tackle issues</s_text></s_node-6></s_node-5><sep/><s_text>Stakeholder communications</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>What are their information needs?</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>Information required/needed</s_text><sep/><s_text>Level of detail and timing</s_text><sep/><s_text>What do/don't we want them to know?</s_text></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>What are the best channels?</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>Meetings, consultations, questionnaires</s_text><sep/><s_text>Direct- leaflets, newsletters, exhibitions etc</s_text><sep/><s_text>Indirect... PR, conferences, sponsorships</s_text></s_node-6></s_node-5></s_node-4></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Definition of the environment</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>"The forces external to the marketing management function of the firm that impinge on the marketing managements ability to develop and maintain successful transactions with its customers"</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Macro</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Macro Marketing</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>"The area of study of the nations exchange process, within its own borders, in which political, cultural, social, and economic interactions are examined"</s_text><sep/><s_text>"To manage a business well is to manage its future and to manage a future is to manage information"</s_text></s_node-4><sep/><s_text>The Macro Environment</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>P.E.S.T.L.E</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>Political</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>"Laws, government agencies, regulations and pressure groups that influence and limit various organisations in a given society"</s_text><sep/><s_text>Positive impacts of governmental/ legal factors...</s_text><s_node-7><s_text>Facilitates desirable social change e.g. equal pay, equal opportunities</s_text><sep/><s_text>Corrects markets i.e. makes sure they are fair and competitive</s_text><sep/><s_text>Encourages further knowledge e.g. research</s_text><sep/><s_text>Reassurance to the public</s_text></s_node-7></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Economic</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>The economic environment consists of factors that affect consumer purchasing power and spending patterns"</s_text><sep/><s_text>The money cycle</s_text><s_node-7><s_text>There are injections and leakages to and from the money cycle</s_text><s_node-8><s_text>Injections</s_text><s_node-9><s_text>Investments</s_text><sep/><s_text>Government spending</s_text><sep/><s_text>Exports</s_text></s_node-9><sep/><s_text>Leakages</s_text><s_node-9><s_text>Savings</s_text><sep/><s_text>Taxation</s_text><sep/><s_text>Imports</s_text></s_node-9></s_node-8><sep/><s_text>These injections and leakages affect expenditure and income, and hence the movement of resources and goods for companies.</s_text></s_node-7><sep/><s_text>International trade</s_text><s_node-7><s_text>Why is international trade so attractive to domestic firms?</s_text><s_node-8><s_text>A global market allows for comparative marketing studies</s_text><sep/><s_text>International trade allows for more competition and choice for consumers</s_text><sep/><s_text>World markets allow for economies of scale and cost advantage</s_text><sep/><s_text>Trade brings contact, cultural understanding and cooperation</s_text><sep/><s_text>Opening of the tiger economies. Emerging markets in asia.</s_text></s_node-8></s_node-7></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Social</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>Segmentation & Assessment of market potential is related to the analysis of studying human populations in terms of size, density, location, age, sex, race and occupation.</s_text><sep/><s_text>Implications of population trends to the marketer</s_text><s_node-7><s_text>The aggregate demand for goods and services</s_text><sep/><s_text>The demand in different market segments/regions</s_text><sep/><s_text>The availability of labour</s_text><sep/><s_text>The level of dependents in the population</s_text><sep/><s_text>The living standards</s_text></s_node-7></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Technical</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>Consists of the forces that create new technologies, creating new products and market opportunities.</s_text><sep/><s_text>Technological diffusion process (adoption: slow or fast)</s_text><s_node-7><s_text>Profitability</s_text><s_node-8><s_text>is the new technology worth it?</s_text></s_node-8><sep/><s_text>Consequences</s_text><s_node-8><s_text>of not adopting- impact on business</s_text></s_node-8><sep/><s_text>Scale of investment</s_text><s_node-8><s_text>In both soft and hardware</s_text></s_node-8><sep/><s_text>Environmental impact</s_text><s_node-8><s_text>How green is the technology</s_text></s_node-8><sep/><s_text>Acceptance of change</s_text><s_node-8><s_text>Effect 'how we do things'- to what degree</s_text></s_node-8></s_node-7></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Legal</s_text><sep/><s_text>Environmental</s_text></s_node-5></s_node-4></s_node-3></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>Market Research</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>Definition</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>The objective gathering and recording and analysing of all facts about problems relating to the transfer and sales of goods and services from producer to consumer</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Qualitative Research</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Exploratory research used to uncover consumer motives, attitudes and behaviour</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Quantitative Research</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Research that involves data collection from a sufficient volume of customers to allow for statistical analysis</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Primary Data</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Information collected for a specific purpose or issue to be addressed</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Secondary Data</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Information that already exists somewhere, having been collected for another purpose</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Research Methodology</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Research: Primary or Secondary?</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>1. Diagnose the problem (be specific)</s_text><sep/><s_text>2. Initial investigation</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>Secondary data sufficient?</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>Yes</s_text><sep/><s_text>No</s_text><s_node-7><s_text>Use primary data research to fill the gaps</s_text></s_node-7></s_node-6></s_node-5><sep/><s_text>3. Report: conclusions and recommendations</s_text></s_node-4><sep/><s_text>Types of information</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>Quantitative Research</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>Sales history by product, customer, location, order size, distribution, season</s_text><sep/><s_text>£ Market growth, % Growth</s_text><sep/><s_text>Competitor products, prices, advertising spend</s_text><sep/><s_text>Customer number, location, demographics, segment</s_text></s_node-5><sep/><s_text>Qualitative Research</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>Customer perceptions</s_text><sep/><s_text>Buying behaviour</s_text><sep/><s_text>Attitudes and motivations</s_text><sep/><s_text>Packaging</s_text><sep/><s_text>Brand image/ preferences</s_text><sep/><s_text>Reaction to adverts</s_text><sep/><s_text>External factors</s_text><sep/><s_text>Power of stakeholders</s_text><sep/><s_text>DMU's</s_text></s_node-5></s_node-4><sep/><s_text>Secondary Research</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>Internal Desk Research</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>Sales and marketing data</s_text><sep/><s_text>customer databases, EPOS/loyalty</s_text><sep/><s_text>Production and distribution data</s_text><sep/><s_text>General market intelligence</s_text><sep/><s_text>Previous market reports/data</s_text><sep/><s_text>Free, quick and easy</s_text></s_node-5><sep/><s_text>External Desk Research</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>Govt stats</s_text><sep/><s_text>Trade/industry reports and media</s_text><sep/><s_text>Competitors- ads, catalogues, exhibitions</s_text><sep/><s_text>Directories/journals</s_text><sep/><s_text>off the shelf reports (mintel, BRAD)</s_text></s_node-5><sep/><s_text>Problems with secondary research</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>Currency</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>often out of date</s_text></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Accuracy</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>may be uncertain/doubtful</s_text></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Relevance</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>May not quite suit purpose</s_text></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Sufficiency</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>often only part of the solution</s_text></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Availability</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>may be limited</s_text></s_node-6></s_node-5></s_node-4><sep/><s_text>Primary Research</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>Experimental/Observation</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>Lab tests... tastes, colour etc</s_text><sep/><s_text>Product trials... in homes</s_text><sep/><s_text>Product sampling... in store</s_text><sep/><s_text>Test market... new product, advert etc</s_text><sep/><s_text>Hidden cameras... in store cctv</s_text><sep/><s_text>may be time consuming and expensive</s_text></s_node-5><sep/><s_text>Sampling and surveys</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>Statistical sample of population</s_text><sep/><s_text>may use structured questionnaire</s_text><sep/><s_text>may use semi structured talk guides</s_text><sep/><s_text>Face to face, street, interview, doorstep</s_text><sep/><s_text>Distance...mail, phone, e-mail, fax etc</s_text><sep/><s_text>Good for lots of quantitative data</s_text></s_node-5><sep/><s_text>qualitative methods for primary research</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>Non statistical methods</s_text><sep/><s_text>Aim for depth not breadth</s_text><sep/><s_text>In depth interviews. One to one.</s_text><sep/><s_text>Focus/discussion groups 7-12 people</s_text><sep/><s_text>Projective... "my mate"</s_text><sep/><s_text>Can be used to add depth to quantitative data</s_text></s_node-5></s_node-4></s_node-3></s_node-2></s_node-1></s_node-0></s_map>

<s_map><s_node-0><s_text>Phrases = Group of related words that do not include a subject and verb</s_text><s_node-1><s_text>Noun Phrase = noun + modifier/s</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>The long and winding road</s_text></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>Prepositional Phrase = a preposition + noun or pronoun</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>outside the building</s_text></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>Appositive Phrase = renaming or amplifying a word immediately preceeding</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>My favourite music, Gregorian chant, is playing.</s_text></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>Particple Phrase = verbals ending in -ing or -ed + complements or modifiers, and acting as an ADJECTIVE.</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>Working around the clock, the firefighters put out the fire</s_text></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>Gerund Phrase = verbals that end in -ing and that act as nouns</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>Cramming for tests is not a good strategy</s_text></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>Infinitive Phrase = an infinitive + modifiers or complements. Functions as a noun/adjective/adverb</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>To subsidize child care is very expensive</s_text></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>Absolute Phrase = Noun or Pronoun + a participle</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>Their faces beaming, they collected the prize.</s_text></s_node-2></s_node-1></s_node-0></s_map>
